## Proprietary Knowledge Document: Commerce Knowledge

1. The official color scheme for the Commerce page is primary dark Mangeta (#8B008B) and secondary orange (#FF8A5B).

4. The launch date for version 2.0 is Q3 2026. Introduction to Commerce. Commerce is trade and aids to trade. It aims at the distribution of goods and services in order to satisfy human wants and needs. Trade is the buying and selling of goods and services with a view of trying profit. There are two types of trade namely; home (local) trade and International (foreign) trade. Aids to trade are commercial activities or services that assist trade to take place. Commercial activities. Commercial activities are all activities concerned with the distribution of goods and services. They include Trade which is necessary for the purchase and sell of goods and services which include raw materials such as timber, cotton, and finished goods such as equipment, books, clothes, services such as entertainment, tourism. And Trade which is done for a profit - Also they include Aids to trade which makes trade to be possible or smoothens or helps in the distribution of goods and services. The importance of commercial services in trade. WABTIC is the acronym for Warehousing, Advertising, Banking, Transport, Insurance, and Communication, which Aids to trade. Commercial services are aids to trade (WABTIC) that help to make trade possible in the following ways: Warehousing. Storing raw materials awaiting processing. By storing finished goods awaiting sale. Protecting goods against bad elements such as unfavourable weather, fire, theft, etc. By storing goods, warehousing prevents shortages. helps in stabilizing prices. Stores dutiable goods in bonded warehouses until after duty is paid. Transport. Delivering equipment and raw materials to industries. Delivering finished goods to local and international markets. Moving workers to and from their work places to enhance production. Carrying company executives and agents to far places in order to meet their clients. Advertising. By informing the members of public on the availability of goods and services on the market. Persuading potential customers to buy the goods and services available. By informing the public on job vacancies with a view of recruiting new staff. By Informing/spreading awareness on matters of public interest. Banking. Finances the traders by means of loans and overdrafts. Safe-guards the traderâ€™s money and other valuables. Facilitates the payment of huge sums through cheques. Offers special facilities to traders such as standing orders, direct debits, credit transfers, discounting bills of exchange, etc. Insurance. Compensates/ restores/indemnifies traders in case of a risk occurring. Protects traders against financial losses resulting from either fire, theft, etc. And against claims from third parties. In terms of life assurance, it provides a saving plan to surviving dependents. Provides confidence or encouragement to traders to go into huge businesses without fear of making a loss. Communication. Informs the public on the availability of goods and services on the market. Allows customers and suppliers to contact each other speedily. By means of telephone, facsimile (fax), letters, electronic mail (e-mail), etc. Original goods are goods that are produced and regarded as durable, expensive and attractive. Quality goods refer to products that meet customer expectations in terms of performance, durability, and aesthetics. They are reliable, safe, and compliant with industry standards. Quality goods offer a fair price-to-quality ratio, providing value to customers. Substandard goods are products that fail to meet customer expectations in terms of quality, performance, and reliability. Counterfeit goods are fake or unauthorised replicas of real products. Specialisation refers to the process where individuals, businesses, or countries focus on producing specific goods or services efficiently. This leads to higher productivity, better quality, and cost reduction. It encourages trade, as specialized entities exchange their products with others. Specialisation also promotes expertise and innovation in a particular field. However, it may create dependency on other producers for goods and services.
